ID	1.4.3.7

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Candida boidinii   <1>
PR	#2# Octopus vulgaris   <3>
PR	#3# Faxonius limosus   (#3# class A TEM-2 enzyme Escherichia coli <2>)
	<2>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	D-glutamate oxidase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	D-glutamate:oxygen oxidoreductase (deaminating)


SYNONYMS
SY	 D-glutamic oxidase
SY	 D-glutamic acid oxidase

REACTION
RE	D-glutamate + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction
RT	oxidative deamination

SOURCE_TISSUE
ST	#1# cell culture <1>
ST	#2# hepatopancreas <3>
ST	#3# antennal gland <2>

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#1,2,3# D-aspartate + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + NH3 + H2O2 (#2# 70%
	higher activity with pure oxygen than in air <3>; #3# 20% higher
	activity with pure oxygen than in air <2>; #1,2# poorer substrate than
	D-glutamate <1,3>) <1,2,3>
NSP	#1,2,3# D-glutamate + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2 (#3#
	highly specific, no deamination of other D-amino acids found, 30%
	higher activity with pure oxygen than in air <2>; #1,2# better
	substrate than D-aspartate <1,3>; #2# highly specific, 70% higher
	activity with pure oxygen than in air <3>) <1,2,3>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1# N-methyl-D-aspartate + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + methylamine + H2O2
	(#1# much poorer substrate than D-glutamate or D-aspartate <1>) <1>
SP	#1,2,3# D-aspartate + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + NH3 + H2O2 (#2# 70%
	higher activity with pure oxygen than in air <3>; #3# 20% higher
	activity with pure oxygen than in air <2>; #1,2# poorer substrate than
	D-glutamate <1,3>) <1,2,3>
SP	#1,2,3# D-glutamate + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2 (#3#
	highly specific, no deamination of other D-amino acids found, 30%
	higher activity with pure oxygen than in air <2>; #1,2# better
	substrate than D-aspartate <1,3>; #2# highly specific, 70% higher
	activity with pure oxygen than in air <3>) <1,2,3>

KM_VALUE
KM	#2# 8 {D-glutamate}  <3>
KM	#2# 4.5 {D-Aspartate}  <3>
KM	#3# 5.4 {D-Aspartate}  <2>
KM	#3# 15.2 {D-glutamate}  <2>

PH_OPTIMUM
PHO	#1# 7 <1>
PHO	#2# 8.1-8.3 <3>
PHO	#3# 9 (#3# with D-glutamate <2>) <2>

SPECIFIC_ACTIVITY
SA	#3# 0.23 <2>

TEMPERATURE_OPTIMUM
TO	#1# 37 <1>

COFACTOR
CF	#1,2# FAD (#1,2# cannot be replaced by FMN <1,3>) <1,3>

ACTIVATING_COMPOUND
AC	#2# ethanol (#2# 2fold activation in the presence of ethanol <3>) <3>

INHIBITORS
IN	#1# Glutarate (#1# competitive inhibitor <1>) <1>
IN	#1# D-malate (#1# competitive inhibitor <1>) <1>
IN	#1# m-tartrate (#1# competitive inhibitor <1>) <1>
IN	#2# iodoacetate (#2# 68% inhibition at 0.1 mM <3>) <3>
IN	#2# urethane (#2# 31% inhibition at 10 mM <3>) <3>
IN	#2# o-Iodosobenzoate (#2# 32% inhibition at 0.1 mM <3>) <3>
IN	#2,3# Veronal (#3# strong inhibition <2>; #2# 60% inhibition at 8 mM
	<3>) <2,3>
IN	#2,3# p-chloromercuribenzoate (#3# 95% inhibition at 0.1 mM <2>; #2#
	74% inhibition at 0.01 mM <3>) <2,3>
IN	#3# L-glutamate (#3# slight inhibition at 100 mM <2>) <2>
IN	#3# L-aspartate (#3# slight inhibition at 100 mM <2>) <2>
IN	#3# succinate (#3# slight inhibition at 1 mM <2>) <2>
IN	#3# iodoacetamide (#3# 64% inhibition at 1 mM <2>) <2>

MOLECULAR_WEIGHT
MW	#1# 43000 (#1# gel filtration <1>) <1>
MW	#1# 45000 (#1# 1 * 45000, SDS-PAGE <1>) <1>

SUBUNITS
SU	#1# monomer (#1# 1 * 45000, SDS-PAGE <1>) <1>

PURIFICATION
PU	#1# (to homogeneity) <1>
PU	#2# (to homogeneity, precipitation techniques, calcium phosphate gel
	treatment) <3>
PU	#3# (partial) <2>

GENERAL_STABILITY
GS	#3# (very stable) <2>

STORAGE_STABILITY
SS	#3# (-30°C, no loss of activity for several months) <2>

TEMPERATURE_STABILITY
TS	#3# 21 (#3# stable for more than 5 h <2>) <2>

REFERENCE
RF	<1> Fukunaga, S.; Yno, S.; Takahashi, M.; Taguchi, S.; Kera, Y.; Odani,
	S.; Yamada, R.H.: Purification and properties of D-glutamate oxidase
	from Candida boidinii 2201. J. Ferment. Bioeng. (1998) 85, 579-583.
	{Pubmed:4387700} (c)
RF	<2> Urich, K.: D-Glutamtoxydase aus der Antennendruse des Flusskrebses
	Orconectes limosus: Reinigung und Charakterisierung. Z. Naturforsch. B
	(1968) 23, 1508-1511. {Pubmed:} (c)
RF	<3> Rocca, E.; Ghiretti, F.: Purification and properties of D-glutamic
	acid oxidase from Octopus vulgaris Lam.. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. (1958)
	77, 336-349. {Pubmed:13583997} (c)

ACTIVATING_COMPOUND
AC	#2# ethanol (#2# 2fold activation in the presence of ethanol <3>) <3>

ID	1.4.3.15

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Neurospora crassa   <2>
PR	#2# Vanrija humicola   <3>
PR	#3# Aspergillus ustus   <1>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	D-glutamate(D-aspartate) oxidase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	D-glutamate(D-aspartate):oxygen oxidoreductase (deaminating)


SYNONYMS
SY	 D-glutamic-aspartic oxidase
SY	 D-monoaminodicarboxylic acid oxidase
SY	#2# ChDASPO <3>

REACTION
RE	D-aspartate + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + NH3 + H2O2
RE	D-glutamate + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction
RT	oxidative deamination

SOURCE_TISSUE
ST	#3# mycelium <1>

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#2,3# D-glutamic acid + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2 (#2#
	enzyme is also involved in the detoxification of D-glutamate, although
	enzyme induction by this amino acid is very limited <3>) <1,3>
NSP	#2,3# D-aspartic acid + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + NH3 + H2O2 (#2# DASPO
	plays an essential role in the assimilation of D-aspartate and acts as
	a detoxifying agent for D-aspartate <3>) <1,3>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1,2,3# D-glutamic acid + H2O + O2 = 2-oxoglutarate + NH3 + H2O2 (#3#
	D-glutamate and D-aspartate are oxidized at the same rate <1>; #2#
	enzyme is also involved in the detoxification of D-glutamate, although
	enzyme induction by this amino acid is very limited <3>) <1,2,3>
SP	#1,2,3# D-aspartic acid + H2O + O2 = oxaloacetate + NH3 + H2O2 (#3#
	D-glutamate and D-aspartate are oxidized at the same rate <1>; #2#
	DASPO plays an essential role in the assimilation of D-aspartate and
	acts as a detoxifying agent for D-aspartate <3>) <1,2,3>
SP	#3# more = ? (#3# DL-alpha-aminoadipic acid not deaminated,
	alpha-aminomalonic acid not deaminated, possible acceptors: oxygen,
	ferricyanide, 2,6-dichlorophenol-indophenol and methylene blue <1>) {}
	<1>

TURNOVER_NUMBER
TN	#3# 0.0833 {D-glutamate}  <1>

TEMPERATURE_OPTIMUM
TO	#3# 30 (#3# assay at <1>) <1>

COFACTOR
CF	#3# FAD (#3# flavoprotein <1>) <1>

INHIBITORS
IN	#3# KCN (#3# remarkable inhibition at 1 mM, inhibition is only slight
	with 2,6-dichlorophenol-indophenol electron acceptor but higher when
	indophenol is used <1>) <1>
IN	#3# FMN (#3# competes with FAD <1>) <1>

PURIFICATION
PU	#3# (90% pure) <1>

GENERAL_STABILITY
GS	#3# (very labile when FAD is removed from the enzyme) <1>

STORAGE_STABILITY
SS	#3# (-20°C, several months) <1>

REFERENCE
RF	<1> Mitzushima, S: Studies on the metabolism of D-amino acid in
	microorganisms. Part 4. On the nature of the purified
	D-glutamic-aspartic oxidase of Aspergillus ustus. J. Gen. Appl.
	Microbiol. (1957) 3, 233-239. {Pubmed:}
RF	<2> Onishi, E.; Macleod, H.; Horowitz, N.H.: Mutants of Neurospora
	deficient in D-amio-acid oxidase. J. Biol. Chem. (1962) 237, 138-142.
	{Pubmed:14481396}
RF	<3> Takahashi, S.; Kakuichi, T.; Fujii, K.; Kera, Y.; Yamada, R.:
	Physiological role of D-aspartate oxidase in the assimilation and
	detoxification of D-aspartate in the yeast Cryptococcus humicola. Yeast
	(2005) 22, 1203-1212. {Pubmed:16278929}

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Bacillus circulans   <1,2,3,4,5,6>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	peptidyl-glutaminase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	peptidyl-L-glutamine amidohydrolase


SYNONYMS
SY	 PGase
SY	 peptidoglutaminase I
SY	 peptidoglutaminase

REACTION
RE	alpha-N-peptidyl-L-glutamine + H2O = alpha-N-peptidyl-L-glutamate + NH3

REACTION_TYPE
RT	hydrolysis of amide bond

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#1# more = ? (#1# enzyme catalyzes the hydrolysis of gamma-amide of
	glutamine whose alpha-amino and/or alpha-carboxyl group participates in
	peptide bond formation <2>) {} <2>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1# more = ? (#1# enzyme catalyzes the hydrolysis of gamma-amide of
	glutamine whose alpha-amino and/or alpha-carboxyl group participates in
	peptide bond formation <2>) {} <2>
SP	#1# L-Gln + H2O = L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln + H2O = benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu + NH3
	<1,3,4,5>
SP	#1# benzyloxycarbonyl-D-Gln + H2O = benzyloxycarbonyl-D-Glu + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# N-acetyl-L-Gln + H2O = N-acetyl-L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# L-Tyr-L-Gln + H2O = L-Tyr-L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# L-Pro-L-Gln + H2O = L-Pro-L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# Gly-L-Gln + H2O = Gly-L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# L-Leu-Gly-L-Gln + H2O = L-Leu-Gly-L-Glu + NH3 <1,3,5>
SP	#1# L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-L-Gln + H2O = L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-L-Glu + NH3 (#1#
	peptidoglutaminase I <1>) <1,3>
SP	#1# Gly-L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-L-Gln + H2O = Gly-L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-L-Glu + NH3
	(#1# peptidoglutaminase I <1>) <1,3>
SP	#1# L-Gln-Gly + H2O + H2O = L-Glu-Gly + NH3 (#1# peptidoglutaminase II
	<1,3>) <1,3,5>
SP	#1# benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-L-Pro + H2O = benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu-L-Pro
	+ NH3 (#1# peptidoglutaminase II <1,3>) <1,3>
SP	#1# tert-amyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-Pro + H2O =
	tert-amyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu-L-Leu-Gly + NH3 (#1# peptidoglutaminase II
	<1,3>) <1,3>
SP	#1# tert-amyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-L-Leu-Gly + H2O =
	tert-amyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu-L-Leu-Gly + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-Gly + H2O = benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu-Gly +
	NH3 (#1# peptidoglutaminase II <1,3>) <1,3>
SP	#1# benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-Gly methyl ester + H2O =
	benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Glu-Gly methyl ester + NH3 (#1# peptidoglutaminase
	II <1,3>) <1,3>
SP	#1# L-Phe-L-Gln-Gly + H2O = L-Phe-L-Glu-Gly + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# L-Ser-L-Gln-Gly + H2O = L-Ser-L-Glu-Gly + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# L-Lys-L-Gln-Gly + H2O = L-Lys-L-Glu-Gly + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# L-His-L-Ser-L-Gln-Gly-L-Thr-L-Phe-L-Thr + H2O =
	L-His-L-Ser-L-Glu-Gly-L-Thr-L-Phe-L-Thr + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# L-Ile-L-Gln-L-Asn-L-CysH-L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-acetate + H2O =
	L-Ile-L-Glu-L-Asn-L-CysH-L-Pro-L-Leu-Gly-acetate + NH3 <1,3>
SP	#1# phthaloyl-DL-Gln + H2O = ? <5>

KM_VALUE
KM	#1# 0.1 {N-acetyl-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.16 {L-Tyr-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.21 {benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-L-Pro}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.11 {benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.12 {tert-amyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln-L-Pro}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.19 {L-Pro-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.33 {Gly-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 0.35 {Leu-Gly-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 5 {L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 23.3 {Leu-Gly-L-Gln}  <1,3>
KM	#1# 1.57 {benzyloxycarbonyl-D-Gln}  <1,3>

PH_OPTIMUM
PHO	#1# 8 (#1# hydrolysis of benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln <3>) <3>
PHO	#1# 7.5 <5>

SPECIFIC_ACTIVITY
SA	#1# 303.0 <1,4>
SA	#1# 65.5 <5>
SA	#1# 205.3 <6>

TEMPERATURE_OPTIMUM
TO	#1# 55 (#1# hydrolysis of benzyloxycarbonyl-L-Gln <3>) <3>

INHIBITORS
IN	#1# Cu2+ <5>
IN	#1# Hg2+ (#1# HgCl2 <3>) <3,5>
IN	#1# N-bromosuccinimide <3>
IN	#1# AgNO3 <3>
IN	#1# sodium lauryl sulfate <3>

MOLECULAR_WEIGHT
MW	#1# 90000 (#1# gel filtration <4>) <4,6>
MW	#1# 89000 (#1# equilibrium sedimentation <2>) <2>
MW	#1# 42000 (#1# 2 * 42000, peptidoglutaminase I, SDS-PAGE <1>) <1>

POSTTRANSLATIONAL_MODIFICATION
PM	#1# no modification (#1# no carbohydrate detected <2>) <2>

SUBUNITS
SU	#1# dimer (#1# 2 * 42000, peptidoglutaminase I, SDS-PAGE <1>) <1>

PURIFICATION
PU	#1# <1,4,5,6>

PH_STABILITY
PHS	#1# 5-12.5 (#1# 40°C, 1 h, stable <3>; #1# 1°C, 22 h, stable <3>) <3>

TEMPERATURE_STABILITY
TS	#1# 55 (#1# 10 min, complete inactivation <3>) <3>
TS	#1# 40 (#1# 10 min, stable up to <3>) <3>

REFERENCE
RF	<1> Kikuchi, M.; Sakaguchi, K.: Peptidoglutaminase (Bacillus
	circulans). Methods Enzymol. (1976) 45B, 485-492. {Pubmed:1012012} (c)

	(c)

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Klebsiella aerogenes   <3>
PR	#2# Micrococcus sp.   <1,2>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	apiose 1-reductase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	D-apiitol:NAD+ 1-oxidoreductase


SYNONYMS
SY	 D-apiose reductase
SY	 D-apiitol reductase

REACTION
RE	D-apiitol + NAD+ = D-apiose + NADH + H+

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#2# D-apiitol + NAD+ = D-apiose + NADH {} <1>
NSP	#2# D-apiitol + NAD+ = D-apiose + NADH {r} <1>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1# D-ribulose + NADH = D-ribitol + NAD+ (#1# 8.5% activity of D-apiose
	reduction, 5.5% of D-apiitol oxidation <3>) {r} <3>
SP	#1# D-erythrose + NADH = meso-erythritol + NAD+ (#1# 1.5% activity of
	D-apiose reduction, 1% of D-apiitol oxidation <3>) {r} <3>
SP	#1# D-mannitol + NAD+ = D-mannose + NADH + H+ (#1# 1% activity of
	D-apiitol oxidation <3>) <3>
SP	#1,2# D-apiitol + NAD+ = D-apiose + NADH {} <1,2,3>
SP	#1,2# D-apiitol + NAD+ = D-apiose + NADH {r} <1,2,3>
SP	#2# meso-erythritol + NAD+ = D-erythrose + NADH (#2# 13% activity of
	D-apiitol oxidation <1>) {} <1,2>
SP	#2# meso-erythritol + NAD+ = D-erythrose + NADH (#2# 13% activity of
	D-apiitol oxidation <1>) {ir} <1,2>
SP	#2# myo-inositol + NAD+ = keto-inositol + NADH (#2# 38% activity of
	D-apiitol oxidation <1>) {} <1,2>
SP	#2# myo-inositol + NAD+ = keto-inositol + NADH (#2# 38% activity of
	D-apiitol oxidation <1>) <1,2>

KM_VALUE
KM	#1# 20 {D-apiose}  (#1# enzyme activity in crude extracts <3>) <3>
KM	#1# 10 {D-apiitol}  (#1# enzyme activity in crude extracts <3>) <3>
KM	#2# 0.015 {NADH}  <1,2>
KM	#2# 0.35 {NAD+}  <1,2>
KM	#2# 11.6 {D-apiitol}  <1,2>
KM	#2# 71.4 {D-apiose}  <1,2>

PH_OPTIMUM
PHO	#1# 10.5 (#1# oxidation of D-apiitol, enzyme activity in crude extracts
	<3>) <3>
PHO	#1,2# 7.5 (#2# reduction of D-apiose <1>; #1# reduction of D-apiose,
	enzyme activity in crude extracts <3>) <1,3>
PHO	#2# 10 (#2# oxidation of D-apiitol <1>) <1>

SPECIFIC_ACTIVITY
SA	#2# 0.102 <1,2>

COFACTOR
CF	#1,2# NAD+ <1,2,3>

INHIBITORS
IN	#2# NADH (#2# 0.1 mM <1>) <1>

MOLECULAR_WEIGHT
MW	#2# 110000 (#2# sucrose density centrifugation, gel filtration <2>) <2>
MW	#2# 115000 (#2# sucrose density centrifugation, gel filtration <1>) <1>

PURIFICATION
PU	#2# <2>
PU	#2# (streptomycin sulfate, calcium phosphate gel, ethanol
	precipitation, DEAE-cellulose, Sephadex G-200) <1>

STORAGE_STABILITY
SS	#2# (-20°C, several weeks, no loss of activity) <1>

REFERENCE
RF	<1> Chandrsekaran, E.V.; Davila, M.; Mendicino, J.: D-Apiitol
	dehydrogenase from bacteria. Methods Enzymol. (1982) 89, 228-232.
	{Pubmed:}
RF	<2> Hanna, R.; Picken, M.; Mendicino, J.: Purification of a specific
	D-Apiitol dehydrogenase from a Micrococcus isolated from the surface of
	germinating parsley seeds. Biochim. Biophys. Acta (1973) 315, 259-271.
	{Pubmed:}
RF	<3> Neal, D.L.; Kindel, P.K.: D-Apiose reductase from Aerobacter
	aerogenes. J. Bacteriol. (1970) 101, 910-915. {Pubmed:4314545}

ID	1.1.1.117

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Rattus norvegicus   <5>
PR	#2# Pseudomonas sp.   <2,3,4>
PR	#3# Candida albicans   <1>
PR	#4# Saccharomyces cerevisiae P38115 UniProt <6>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	D-arabinose 1-dehydrogenase [NAD(P)+]


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	D-arabinose:NAD(P)+ 1-oxidoreductase


SYNONYMS
SY	 dehydrogenase, D-arabinose (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
	(phosphate))
SY	#4# D-arabinose dehydrogenase <6>
SY	#4# ARA1 <6>

REACTION
RE	D-arabinose + NAD(P)+ = D-arabinono-1,4-lactone + NAD(P)H + H+

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction

SOURCE_TISSUE
ST	#1# liver <5>

LOCALIZATION
LO	#1,2,3# cytoplasm <1,2,3,4,5>

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#1,2,3# D-arabinose + NAD(P)+ = D-arabino-1,4-lactone + NAD(P)H (#2#
	specific for sugars of the optical configuration of L-galactose <3>)
	<1,2,3,4,5>
NSP	#4# D-arabinose + NADP+ = D-arabinono-1,4-lactone + NADPH + H+ <6>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1,2,3# D-arabinose + NAD(P)+ = D-arabino-1,4-lactone + NAD(P)H (#2#
	alpha-anomer preferred <3>; #2# specific for sugars of the optical
	configuration of L-galactose <3>) <1,2,3,4,5>
SP	#2# L-colitose + NAD(P)+ = 3,6-dideoxy-L-galactono-1,5-lactone +
	NAD(P)H (#2# i.e. 3,6-dideoxy-L-galactose <3>) <3>
SP	#2,3# L-galactose + NADP+ = L-galactono-1,4-lactone + NADPH + H+ (#2#
	beta-anomer preferred <3>) <1,3>
SP	#2,3# L-fucose + NADP+ = 6-deoxy-L-galactono-1,4-lactone + NADPH + H+
	(#2# i.e. 6-deoxy-L-galactose <3>) <1,3>
SP	#3# L-xylose + NADP+ = L-xylono-1,4-lactone + NADPH <1>
SP	#4# D-arabinose + NADP+ = D-arabinono-1,4-lactone + NADPH + H+ <6>

	for NADP+ is considerably higher <3>) <2,3,4>

	<6>

STORAGE_STABILITY
SS	#2# (frozen, purified enzyme stable for many months) <2>
SS	#2# (lyophilized, purified enzyme stable for many months) <2>
SS	#2# (-20°C, acetone-dried cells retain full activity for extended
	periods of time) <2>
SS	#2# (4°C, stable as ammonium sulfate precipitate) <2>

TEMPERATURE_STABILITY
TS	#2# 50 (#2# after 10 min 90% of maximal activity retained <2>) <2>
TS	#2# 58 (#2# half-life of 20 s is increased to 80 s in presence of
	cofactor, in both cases biphasic inactivation curve <4>) <4>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	glucose 1-dehydrogenase (NADP+)


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	D-glucose:NADP+ 1-oxidoreductase


SYNONYMS
SY	 nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate-linked aldohexose
	dehydrogenase
SY	 NADP-linked aldohexose dehydrogenase
SY	 dehydrogenase, glucose (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate)
SY	 NADP-dependent glucose dehydrogenase
SY	#1# GlcDH 2 <10>
SY	#1,4,9# glucose dehydrogenase <9,10,14>
SY	#10# STK_17040 (#10# locus name <16>) <16>
SY	#11# NAD(P)-dependent GDH <16>
SY	#11# glucose-1-dehydrogenase <16>
SY	#11# nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (phosphate)-dependent
	glucose-1-dehydrogenase <16>
SY	#4,9# GlcDH <9,14,17>
SY	#9# halophilic glucose dehydrogenase <13>
SY	#9# NAD(P)+ glucose dehydrogenase <13>

SY	#9,10,11# GDH <13,16>

REACTION
RE	D-glucose + NADP+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH + H+

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction

SOURCE_TISSUE
ST	#2# commercial preparation <12>

	unphosphorylated glucose as substrate <10>) <10,16>

	unphosphorylated glucose as substrate <10>) {r} <10,16>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1,4,5,6,10,11# D-glucose + NADP+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH + H+
	(#5# 4% of the reverse reaction when assayed with D-glucono-1,5-lactone
	and NADPH at neutral or weak alkaline pH <3>; #1# unphosphorylated
	glucose as substrate <10>; #10# the enzyme prefers NADP+ over NAD+ as
	the cofactor. It shows a larger Km value for NAD+ (4.5 mM) than for
	NADP+ (0.12 mM) at 80°C. At 25°C the Km values are 0.069 mM for NAD+
	and 0.0059 mM for NADP+ <16>) <1,2,3,10,11,16>
SP	#1,4,5,6,10,11# D-glucose + NADP+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH + H+
	(#5# 4% of the reverse reaction when assayed with D-glucono-1,5-lactone
	and NADPH at neutral or weak alkaline pH <3>; #1# unphosphorylated
	glucose as substrate <10>; #10# the enzyme prefers NADP+ over NAD+ as
	the cofactor. It shows a larger Km value for NAD+ (4.5 mM) than for
	NADP+ (0.12 mM) at 80°C. At 25°C the Km values are 0.069 mM for NAD+
	and 0.0059 mM for NADP+ <16>) {} <1,2,3,10,11,16>
SP	#1,4,5,6,10,11# D-glucose + NADP+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH + H+
	(#5# 4% of the reverse reaction when assayed with D-glucono-1,5-lactone
	and NADPH at neutral or weak alkaline pH <3>; #1# unphosphorylated
	glucose as substrate <10>; #10# the enzyme prefers NADP+ over NAD+ as
	the cofactor. It shows a larger Km value for NAD+ (4.5 mM) than for
	NADP+ (0.12 mM) at 80°C. At 25°C the Km values are 0.069 mM for NAD+
	and 0.0059 mM for NADP+ <16>) {r} <1,2,3,10,11,16>

	1,N6-ethanoadenine-NADPH {r} <4>

SP	#6# 2-deoxy-D-glucose + NADP+ = 2-deoxy-D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH +
	H+ <1,2>
SP	#9# D-glucose + NAD+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADH + H+ <13>
SP	#9# beta-D-glucose + NADP+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADPH + H+ (#9#
	the enzyme has a strong preference for NADP+ over NAD+ <13>) <13,14>
SP	#9# beta-D-glucose + NAD+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NADH + H+ (#9# the
	enzyme has a strong preference for NADP+ over NAD+ <13>) <13>
SP	#9# D-glucose + NAD(P)+ = D-glucono-1,5-lactone + NAD(P)H + H+ <13>
SP	#9# beta-D-glucose + NAD+ = ? (#9# activity with NAD+ is 26% of the
	activity with NADP+ <7>) <7>
SP	#9# beta-D-glucose + NADP+ = ? (#9# activity with NAD+ is 26% of the
	activity with NADP+. The enzyme shows also activity with D-fucose and
	NADP+ (at 18% compared to the activity with beta-D-glucose and NADP+),
	with D-galactose and NADP+ (at 13% compared to the activity with
	beta-D-glucose and NADP+), with D-xylose and NAD+ (at 79% compared to
	the activity with beta-D-glucose and NADP+), with D-xylose and NADP+
	(at 88% compared to the activity with beta-D-glucose and NADP+) <7>) <7>

KM	#7# 0.05 {1,N6-ethanoadenine-NADP+}  <4>
KM	#7# 0.02 {NADP+}  <4>
KM	#7# 0.09 {polyethylene glycol(MW 20000)-N6-(2-aminoethyl)-NADP+}  <4>
KM	#7# 0.07 {N1-(2-aminoethyl)-NADP+}  <4>
KM	#8# 2 {D-glucose}  <6>
KM	#8# 0.28 {NADP+}  <6>
KM	#8# 4 {NAD+}  <6>
KM	#9# 0.4 {NAD(P)+}  (#9# with NAD+ as coenzyme <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 24 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme R207I, using NADP+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 1.2 {NAD+}  (#9# pH 8.8, 40°C <7>) <7>
KM	#9# 0.024 {NADP+}  (#9# pH 8.8, 40°C <7>) <7>
KM	#9# 0.035 {NAD(P)+}  (#9# with NADP+ as coenzyme <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 32 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme R207I, using NAD+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 3.9 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# pH 8.8, 40°C <7>) <7>
KM	#9# 80 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme G206D/R207I, using NAD+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 15 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme G206D, using NAD+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 52 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme G206D, using NADP+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 57 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# mutant enzyme G206D/R207I/R208N, using
	NAD+ as cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 31.1 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# wild type enzyme, using NADP+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>
KM	#9# 12.9 {beta-D-glucose}  (#9# wild type enzyme, using NAD+ as
	cosubstrate <13>) <13>

PH_OPTIMUM
PHO	#10# 9 (#10# assay at <16>) <16>
PHO	#5# 8.5-9 (#5# in Tris-buffer <3>) <3>
PHO	#6# 8 (#6# in Tris-buffer <1>) <1>

PH_RANGE
PHR	#6# 7.5-9 (#6# broad range of optimal activity, in Tris-buffer
	consistently higher than that in phosphate-buffers <1>) <1>

SPECIFIC_ACTIVITY
SA	#5# 140.0 <3>
SA	#6# 10.1 <1,2>
SA	#8# -999.0 (#8# 25 mU/mg at 37°C <6>) <6>
SA	#9# 550.0 (#9# pH 8.8, 40°C <7>) <7>

TEMPERATURE_OPTIMUM
TO	#5# 50 <3>

COFACTOR
CF	#4,5,6# NADPH <1,3,11>
CF	#4,5,6,7,9,10,11# NADP+ (#9# the Km value of the wild type enzyme is
	11fold lower for NADP+ than for NAD+, indicating that the enzyme has a
	strong preference for NADP+ <13>; #9# Km-value for NAD+ is 50fold
	higher than Km-value for NADP+ <7>; #10# the enzyme prefers NADP+ over
	NAD+ as the cofactor. It shows a larger Km value for NAD+ (4.5 mM) than
	for NADP+ (0.12 mM) at 80°C. At 25°C the Km values are 0.069 mM for
	NAD+ and 0.0059 mM for NADP+ <16>) <1,2,3,4,7,9,11,13,14,16>
CF	#4,9# NAD+ (#4# poor substrate for wild-type <13>; #9# Km-value for
	NAD+ is 50fold higher than Km-value for NADP+ <7>) <7,13>
CF	#7# N6-(2-aminoethyl)-NADP+ <4>
CF	#7# N1-(2-aminoethyl)-NADP+ <4>
CF	#7# polyethylene glycol(MW 20000)-N6-(2-aminoethyl)-NADP+ <4>
CF	#7# 1,N6-ethanoadenine-NADP+ <4>

ACTIVATING_COMPOUND
AC	#4# Zn2+ <9>
AC	#4# NaCl (#4# triple mutant D172K/D216K/D344K shows its maximum
	activity in a buffer with 0.50-0.75 M NaCl while the wild type protein
	has its maximum activity with 1.5 M NaCl <11>) <11>

INHIBITORS
IN	#4# NAD+ <13>
IN	#4# NADP+ <13>
IN	#4# KCl (#4# at 40°C, half-life in 0.5 M KCl is 86 h for wild-type, and
	114 h for mutant D172K/D216K/D344K, 95 h for mutant D172K, 117 h for
	mutant D216K, 114 h for mutant D344K. At 25°C, half-life in 0.5 M KCl
	is 506 h for wild-type, and 613 h for mutant D172K/D216K/D344K, 630 h
	for mutant D172K, 660 h for mutant D216K, 537 h for mutant D344K <11>)
	<11>
IN	#5# Cu2+ <3>
IN	#5# Hg2+ <3>
IN	#5# Ni2+ <3>
IN	#5# p-chloromercuribenzoate <3>
IN	#5# sulfhydryl reagents <3>
IN	#6# CuSO4 <1,2>
IN	#6# ZnSO4 <1,2>
IN	#6# NADPH (#6# competitive to NADP+ <1>) <1>
IN	#6# more (#6# overview: sugars found to be neither substrates nor
	inhibitors <1>; #6# not: iodoacetate, N-ethylmaleimide,
	p-hydroxymercuribenzoate, 5,5-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzate) <2>) <1,2>
IN	#9# NAD(P)+ <13>
IN	#9# EDTA (#9# 2 mM <7>) <7>

METALS_IONS
ME	#4,9# Zn2+ (#9# dependent on <14>; #4# zinc is an important component
	of the catalytic centre <14>) <14>
ME	#9# Mg2+ (#9# besides KCl/NaCl, the activity also depends on presence
	of bivalent cations. Mg2+ is more effective than Mg2+ or Ni2+ <7>) <7>
ME	#9# Mn2+ (#9# besides KCl/NaCl, the activity also depends on presence
	of bivalent cations. Mn2+ is less effective than Mg2+ and more
	effective than Ni2+ <7>) <7>
ME	#9# Ni2+ (#9# besides KCl/NaCl, the activity also depends on presence
	of bivalent cations. Ni2+ is more effective than Mg2+ or Mn2+ <7>) <7>
ME	#9# NaCl (#9# the activity is dependent on the concentration of NaCl or
	KCl in the activity buffer, being optimal at 1.3 M <7>) <7>
ME	#9# KCl (#9# the activity is dependent on the concentration of NaCl or
	KCl in the activity buffer, being optimal at 1.3 M <7>) <7>
ME	#9# Zinc (#9# a member of the zinc-containing medium chain polyol
	dehydrogenase family <17>) <17>

MOLECULAR_WEIGHT
MW	#4# 39000 <9>
MW	#4# 19500 (#4# 2 * 19500 <9>) <9>
MW	#5# 153000 (#5# gel filtration on Sephadex G-200 <3>) <3>
MW	#5# 40000 (#5# 4 * 40000, SDS-PAGE <3>) <3>
MW	#9# 89000 (#9# gel filtration <7>) <7>
MW	#9# 53000 (#9# 2 * 53000, SDS-PAGE <7>) <7>

SUBUNITS
SU	#4,9# dimer (#9# 2 * 53000, SDS-PAGE <7>; #4# 2 * 19500 <9>) <7,9>
SU	#5# tetramer (#5# 4 * 40000, SDS-PAGE <3>) <3>

APPLICATION
AP	#1# industry (#1# Optimizing whole-cell biocatalysts by integrating a
	recombinant intracellular NADPH regeneration system through
	co-expression of a glucose facilitator from Zymomonas mobilis for
	uptake of unphosphorylated glucose and a NADP+-dependent glucose
	dehydrogenase from Bacillus megaterium that oxidizes glucose to
	gluconolactone. <10>) <10>
AP	#1,3# synthesis (#3# use of enzyme in enzyme-catalyzed synthesis system
	for poly(3-hydroxybutyrate), enzyme catalyzes regeneration of NADPH,
	system yields 5.6 mg of poly(3-hydroxybutyrate), in a 5 ml-reaction
	mixture <8>; #1# Escherichia coli strain expressing both recombinant
	glucose 1-dehydrogenase and a glucose facilitator for uptake of
	unphosphorylated glucose shows a nine times higher initial alpha-pinene
	oxide formation rate corresponding to a sixfold higher yield of 20 mg
	per g cell dry weight after 1.5 h and to a sevenfold increased
	alpha-pinene oxide yield in the presence of glucose compared to
	glucose-free conditions <10>) <8,10>
AP	#2# analysis (#2# method for determination of D-glucose- and
	D-galactose levels in glycoconjugates. The NAD(P)H produced from the
	enzymatic oxidation of the monosaccharides reacts with a
	CuSO4-bathocuproinedisulfonic acid reagent to produce a color complex
	absorbing maximally at 486 nm. With galactose dehydrogenase and glucose
	dehydrogenase serving as the model enzymes, reaction analysis gives a
	linear plot from 2.5 to 250 nmol of sugar. Method has been applicated
	to sugar released by acid hydrolysis from lactose, porcine submaxillary
	mucin and raffinose was quantified <12>) <12>

ENGINEERING
EN	#1# more (#1# Escherichia coli strain expressing both recombinant
	glucose 1-dehydrogenase and a glucose facilitator for uptake of
	unphosphorylated glucose shows a nine times higher initial alpha-pinene
	oxide formation rate corresponding to a sixfold higher yield of 20 mg
	per g cell dry weight after 1.5 h and to a sevenfold increased
	alpha-pinene oxide yield in the presence of glucose compared to
	glucose-free conditions <10>; #1# introduction of both, GLF and GlcDH,
	in P450-overexpressing Escherichia coli should enable the cell to carry
	out a straightforward intracellular cofactor regeneration driven by
	externally added glucose. For the generation of recombinant Escherichia
	coli strains carrying two plasmids, these are transformed successively.
	Firstly, pZY507glf is transformed into Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3).
	Subsequently, competent cells are prepared from a positive
	transformant, and then pETDUETbm-3qm glcdh is transformed. <10>) <10>
EN	#10,11# V254I (#10# mutant has improved kcat and kcat/Km values at both
	25°C and 80°C. The thermal stability of the mutant enzyme was
	comparable to that of the wild-type enzyme. Calculation of the
	energetic contribution of the V254I mutation for the dehydrogenase
	reaction reveals that the mutation destabilizes the
	enzyme-NADPD-glucose ternary complex and reduces the transition-state
	energy, thus enhancing catalysis <16>; #11# the mutant has improved
	kcat and kcat/Km values at both 25°C and 80°C compared to the wild type
	enzyme <16>) <16>
EN	#11# I189V (#11# the mutant has decreased kcat and kcat/Km values at
	both 25°C and 80°C compared to the wild type enzyme <16>) <16>
EN	#4# D172K (#4# mutation in surface residue, mutant protein is slightly
	less halotolerant than wild-type <11>) <11>
EN	#4# D216K (#4# mutation in surface residue, mutant protein is slightly
	less halotolerant than wild-type <11>) <11>
EN	#4# D344K (#4# mutation in surface residue, mutant protein is slightly
	less halotolerant than wild-type <11>) <11>
EN	#4# D172K/D216K/D344K (#4# mutation in surface residue, mutant protein
	is slightly less halotolerant than wild-type <11>) <11>
EN	#4,9# G206D (#4# less efficient with NADP+ than the wild type, 1.6fold
	increase in ratio kcat/Km for NAD+ <13>; #9# prefers NAD+ over NADP+
	<13>; #9# the mutant is less efficient with NADP+ than the wild type
	enzyme, the relation kcat/KNAD+ is 1.6times higher than in the wild
	type, resulting in an enzyme that prefers NAD+ over NADP+ <13>) <13>
EN	#4,9# R207I (#9# less efficient with NAD+ or NADP+ than the wild-type
	enzyme <13>; #4# less efficient with NADP+ than the wild type <13>; #9#
	the mutant is less efficient with NADP+ than the wild type enzyme,
	shows an increase of 48times in Km value with NADP+ when compared with
	the wild type accompanied by a decrease in kcat, which clearly makes
	the R207I mutant less efficient in catalysis with NADP+, the R207I
	substitution also makes the enzyme less efficient with NAD+, with a
	decrease of 4 times in kcat/Km, this substitution also increases the Km
	for glucose <13>) <13>
EN	#4,9# G206D/R207I (#9# active only with NAD+ <13>; #4# no activity with
	NADP+, highest reaction rate with cofactor NAD+ of all mutants tested
	<13>; #9# the mutant shows no activity with NADP+, when the coenzyme
	NAD+ is incubated with this double mutant, it reaches the highest kcat
	value, between 1.5 and 2times higher than the kcat of the wild type
	enzyme with NADP+, and between 3 and 4times higher than the kcat of the
	wild type with NAD+ <13>) <13>
EN	#4,9# G206D/R207I/R208N (#9# active only with NAD+ <13>; #4# no
	activity with NADP+ <13>; #9# the mutant shows no activity with NADP+
	<13>) <13>
EN	#9# D38C (#9# crystallization of a range of binary and ternary
	complexes of the wild-type and a D38C mutant protein <9>) <9>

CLONED
CL	#1# (overexpression in Escherichia coli JM109 for use as a cofactor
	regenerator) <5>
CL	#1# (expression in Escherichia coli, together with a glucose
	facilitator from Zymomonas mobilis for uptake of unphosphorylated
	glucose) <10>
CL	#1# (expression in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) already heterologously
	overexpressing P450 BM-3 QM together with glucose facilitator (GLF)
	from Zymomonas mobilis) <10>
CL	#4# (expression as inclusion bodies in Escherichia coli) <13>
CL	#9# (overexpressed in Escherichia coli) <15>
CL	#9# (expressed in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) cells) <13>
CL	#9# (expressed as recombinant protein in Escherichia coli strain
	BL21(DE3)) <13>
CL	#10# (expression in Escherichia coli) <16>
CL	#11# (expressed in Escherichia coli Rosetta2 (DE3) cells) <16>

CRYSTALLIZATION
CR	#4# <14>
CR	#4# (hanging-drop vapour diffusion) <9>
CR	#5# <3>
CR	#9# (the structures of GlcDH in binary complexes with either NADP+/Zn2+
	or NADPH/Zn2+, a ternary complex with NADP+/Zn2+/glucose, and a
	nonproductive ternary complex with NADP+/Zn2+ /gluconolactone are
	determined from isomorphous crystals, in the presence of zinc (1 mM)
	and either 5 mM NADP+, by using 1.4-1.6 M sodium citrate as the
	precipitant (in 100 mM HEPES, pH 7.0, and 2 M NaCl) or 5 mM NADPH,
	using 67-72% (w/v) 2-methyl-2,4-pentanediol as precipitant (in 100 mM
	HEPES, pH 7.5, and 2 M NaCl)) <14>
CR	#9# (1.6 A structure determination of the enzyme using crystals grown
	under conditions that closely mimic those experienced within the cell
	of the halophile. The structure is compared with nonhalophilic
	homologues. Location of bound counterions in the structure. Analysis of
	protein-solvent interactions to further the understanding of the
	molecular basis of halophilic adaptation) <17>
CR	#9# (hanging-drop vapour-diffusion method at 17°C, crystallization of a
	range of binary and ternary complexes of the wild-type and a D38C
	mutant protein. For most of the complexes, crystals belonging to space
	group I222 are obtained using sodium/potassium citrate as a
	precipitant. For the binary and non-productive ternary complexes with
	NADPH/Zn, it is necessary to replace the citrate with
	2-methyl-2,4-pentanediol. Despite the radical change in conditions, the
	crystals thus formed are isomorphous) <9>
CR	#9# (hanging-drop vapour-diffusion method using sodium citrate as the
	precipitant. Two crystal forms representing the free enzyme and the
	binary complex with NADP+ grow under these conditions. Crystals of form
	I diffract to beyond 3.5 A resolution and belong to the hexagonal space
	group P622, with unit-cell parameters a = b = 89.1, c = 214.6 A, alpha
	= beta = 90°, gamma = 120°. Crystals of form II diffract to greater
	than 2.0 A and belong to the orthorhombic space group I222 or I212121,
	with unit-cell parameters a = 61.8, b = 110.9, c = 151.7 A, alpha =
	beta = gamma = 90°) <15>

PURIFICATION
PU	#4# <9>
PU	#5# (column chromatography on DEAE-Sephadex A-50 and affinty
	chromatography by blue-dextran Sepharose 4B) <3>
PU	#6# (partial) <1,2>
PU	#9# <7,9,13,15,17>
PU	#10# <16>
PU	#11# (HiTrapQ column chromatography and Resource-phenyl column
	chromatography) <16>

RENATURED
REN	#9# <13>

GENERAL_STABILITY
GS	#6# (lyophilization of dilute enzyme solutions, below 0.5 ng/ml,
	results in significant loss of activity) <1,2>
GS	#6# (freezing and thawing: significant loss of activity) <1,2>

STORAGE_STABILITY
SS	#5# (5°C, crystalline preparation in ammonium sulfate, 6 months) <3>
SS	#6# (-20°C, 1 year) <1>
SS	#6# (4°C, pH 5.4 - pH 8.5, 8 weeks) <1>
SS	#9# (4°C, stable for several months) <7>
SS	#9# (4°C, stable for weeks) <13>

TEMPERATURE_STABILITY
TS	#9# 65 (#9# half-life: 56.8 h, in the presence of 3 M NaCl, stability
	decreases significantly with lower salt concentrations <7>) <7>

KCAT_KM_VALUE
KKM	#10,11# 0.092 (#10# pH 9.0, 25°C, mutant enzyme I189V <16>; #11# mutant
	enzyme I189V, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 0.186 (#10# pH 9.0, 25°C, wild-type enzyme <16>; #11# wild type
	enzyme, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 0.31 (#10# pH 9.0, 80°C, mutant enzyme I189V <16>; #11# mutant
	enzyme I189V, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>

	enzyme V254I, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 3.82 (#10# pH 9.0, 25°C, wild-type enzyme <16>; #11# wild type
	enzyme, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>

	enzyme V254I, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>

	enzyme I189V, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>

	enzyme V254I, at pH 9.0 and 25°C <16>) <16>

	enzyme, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 0.365 (#10# pH 9.0, 80°C, mutant enzyme V254I <16>; #11# mutant
	enzyme V254I, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 0.863 (#10# pH 9.0, 80°C, wild-type enzyme <16>; #11# wild type
	enzyme, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#10,11# 0.893 (#10# pH 9.0, 80°C, mutant enzyme I189V <16>; #11# mutant
	enzyme I189V, at pH 9.0 and 80°C <16>) <16>
KKM	#4# 0.015 (#4# wild-type, pH 8.8, 40°C <13>) <13>

	<13>

	<13>

	<13>) <13>

	40°C <13>) <13>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate dehydrogenase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	

///
ID	1.3.1.28
********************************************************************************
*                                                                              *
* Copyrighted by Dietmar Schomburg, Techn. University Braunschweig, GERMANY    *
* Distributed under the License as stated at http:/www.brenda-enzymes.org      *
*                                                                              *
********************************************************************************

PROTEIN
PR	#1# Escherichia coli   <2,3,4,6,7,8>
PR	#2# Klebsiella aerogenes   <1>
PR	#3# Pseudomonas putida   <5>
PR	#4# Streptomyces sp. NTK 937   <9>

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate dehydrogenase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	(2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate:NAD+ oxidoreductase


SYNONYMS
SY	 dehydrogenase, 2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate
SY	 EC 1.1.1.109
SY	 2,3-DHB dehydrogenase
SY	 Cold shock protein CSI14
SY	#1# EntA <7,8>
SY	#1# 2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoic acid dehydrogenase <7>
SY	#4# cbxG (#4# gene name <9>) <9>

REACTION
RE	(2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH + H+ (#1# enzyme functions as an alcohol
	dehydrogenase which oxidizes the C3-hydroxylgroup of the substrate, the
	transient intermediate 2-hydroxy-3-oxo-4,6-cyclohexadiene-1-carboxylate
	undergoes rapid aromatization to give 2,3-dihydroxybenzoate <3>)

REACTION_TYPE
RT	redox reaction
RT	oxidation
RT	reduction

NATURAL_SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
NSP	#4# (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH + H+ {r} <9>
NSP	#4# (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH + H+ <9>

SUBSTRATE_PRODUCT
SP	#1# trans-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH (#1# genetic results suggest that the
	enzyme may also have isochorismate synthase activity <6>) {ir} <3,6>
SP	#1# trans-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH (#1# genetic results suggest that the
	enzyme may also have isochorismate synthase activity <6>) <3,6>
SP	#1# 3-hydroxy-4-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate =
	3-oxo-4-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate + NADH (#1# reversible only with
	3-keto compounds, not with 2-keto compounds <3>) {r} <3>
SP	#1# methyl-2,3-dihydro-3-hydroxybenzoate + NAD+ = 3-hydroxybenzoate +
	NADH {r} <3>
SP	#1# methyl-3-hydroxy-1,4-cyclohexadien-1-carboxylate + NAD+ =
	3-hydroxybenzoate + NADH {r} <3>
SP	#1# cis-3-hydroxy-cyclohexane-1-carboxylate + NAD+ =
	3-oxo-cyclohexane-1-carboxylate + NADH {r} <3>
SP	#1# trans-3-hydroxy-cyclohexane-1-carboxylate + NAD+ =
	3-oxo-cyclohexane-1-carboxylate + NADH {r} <3>
SP	#1# cis-1,3-cyclohexadiene-5,6-diol + NAD+ = ? {r} <3>
SP	#1# trans-1,3-cyclohexadiene-5,6-diol + NAD+ = ? {r} <3>
SP	#1# 2-cyclohexen-1-ol + NAD+ = 1-oxo-2-cyclohexene + NADH {r} <3>
SP	#1# cis-3-hydroxy-4-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate + NAD+ =
	3-oxo-4-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate + NADH + H+ {r} <3>
SP	#1# cis-3,5-cyclohexadiene-1,2-diol + NAD+ = ? {r} <3>
SP	#1# methyl 2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ = ? {r} <3>
SP	#1# trans-3-hydroxy-2-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate + NAD+ = ? {r} <3>
SP	#1# trans-3-hydroxycyclohexane-1-carboxylic acid + NAD+ =
	3-oxo-cyclohexane-1-carboxylate + NADH + H+ {r} <3>
SP	#1,4# (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH + H+ {r} <3,4,9>
SP	#1,4# (2S,3S)-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH + H+ <3,4,9>
SP	#3# 4-trifluoromethyl-2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ =
	4-trifluoromethyl-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NADH (#3# low turnover <5>)
	<5>
SP	#3# 4-isopropyl-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate + NAD+ = ? <5>

TURNOVER_NUMBER
TN	#1# 1 {2-Cyclohexen-1-ol}  <3>
TN	#1# 1 {trans-3,5-cyclohexadiene-1,2-diol}  <3>
TN	#1# 3 {methyl-3-hydroxy-1,4-cyclohexadiene-1-carboxylate}  <3>
TN	#1# 16.7 {cis-3,5-cyclohexadiene-1,2-diol}  <3>
TN	#1# 5 {trans-3-hydroxy-2-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate}  <3>
TN	#1# 5 {cis-3-hydroxycyclohexane-1-carboxylic acid}  <3>

	<5>

SPECIFIC_ACTIVITY
SA	#1# 66.0 <3>
SA	#1# 58.0 <4>

	presence of 0.002 mM iron, enzyme is repressed by high iron
	concentrations <1>) <1>

COFACTOR
CF	#1,2,4# NAD+ (#2# absolutely required <1>) <1,4,9>

INHIBITORS
IN	#1# cis-2-hydroxy-3-cyclohexen-1-carboxylate <3>

	competitive inhibition <5>) <5>

MOLECULAR_WEIGHT
MW	#1# 210000 (#1# gel filtration <4>) <4>
MW	#1# 26000 (#1# x * 26000, deduced from nucleotide sequence <2>) <2>

SUBUNITS
SU	#1# ? (#1# x * 26000, deduced from nucleotide sequence <2>) <2>
SU	#1# tetramer <7>
SU	#1# More (#1# enzyme can form a specific complex with
	2,3-dihydroxybenzoate-AMP ligase EntE. Cross-linked product with a
	molecular mass of more than 250 kDa, suggesting a complex stoichiometry
	of one EntA tetramer and four EntE monomers. Addition of a 4-fold
	excess of EntA to an EntE assay mixture results in a 6fold stimulation
	of EntE activity <8>; #1# enzyme undergoes concentration-dependent
	dimer-tetramer self-association with a KD value of 12.3 microM,
	analytical ultracentrifugation <8>) <8>
SU	#1# octamer (#1# 8 * 26249-26253, deduced from nucleotide sequence
	<4,6>) <4,6>

CLONED
CL	#1# <2,4,6>
CL	#1# (into vector pET15b and expressed in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3)) <7>

CRYSTALLIZATION
CR	#1# (to 2.0 A resolution by hanging-drop method) <7>

PURIFICATION
PU	#1# <4>
PU	#1# (by two IMAC chromatography steps) <7>

GENERAL_STABILITY
GS	#2# (unstable after chromatography on DEAE cellulose) <1>

ID	2.4.1.370

RECOMMENDED_NAME
RN	inositol phosphorylceramide mannosyltransferase


SYSTEMATIC_NAME
SN	GDP-alpha-D-mannose:inositol phospho-(2'R)-2'-hydroxyphytoceramide
	mannosyltransferase


SYNONYMS
SY	 SUR1
SY	 CSH1

REACTION
RE	GDP-alpha-D-mannose + a very-long-chain inositol
	phospho-(2'R)-2'-hydroxyphytoceramide = a very-long-chain
	mannosylinositol phospho-(2'R)-2'-hydroxyphytoceramide + GDP

///
